newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Irish graduates take on Silicon valley.
newsitem.headline: Irish graduates take on Silicon valley.

text.p: Two Dublin university graduates have taken on America's Silicon Valley and developed a product that has made even U.S. computer experts sit up, take notice and invest in their ideas.
Ireland's 3.6 million population could fit neatly into a corner of Silicon Valley. So, too, could a tiny Irish company called Iona Technologies.

But that is not how things have happened for Iona, a developer of highly sophisticated systems software, and the brainchild of Chris Horn and Annrai O'Toole, while both were based in Trinity College, Dublin.
Fascinated by computer technology, they dabbled with the idea of simplifying a method of allowing different computer systems to talk to each other.
Iona broke new ground when it developed a novel product, ORBIX, which provides a tool kit for developers enabling them to access and distribute information in diverse systems.
Their product provides the "communicative glue" to mesh different products, whether deemed "compatible" or not, to allow a user to pick and choose across systems.
"It is an age-old problem ... people have been trying to connect different kinds of component software applications together," said Horn, Iona's chief executive.
"As an analogy, we are providing the pipework that allows you to build your plumbing systems. They can be simple or highly complex," he said.
Iona, still with just a handful of staff members, laboriously prepared the paperwork for its initial public offer on Nasdaq.
Such was their product's success that when their zero-funded "campus start-up" of the 1980s was launched on Nasdaq in February 1997 it was snapped up and is now capitalised at almost $400 million.

The company got its first major break at a trade show in the United States in 1992, when Sun Microsystems Inc. displayed keen interest in their product. Six months later, Sun bought a 25 percent stake in Iona for just $600,000.
"Having Sun as an investor was a significant vote of approval from a major American player and probably gave us more leverage than a venture capitalist could have done at that time," Horn said.
Horn said Sun later offered to buy 100 percent of the company but after lengthy discussions it was decided that Iona would go it alone.
Response to its initial public stock offering was so strong that its suggested price of $18 per share was ignored as the stock jumped to $22 at the open.
Despite a downturn in the entire technology sector shortly after the launch, Iona reported a rise of 145 percent in total revenues to $9.1 million for the first quarter ended March 30.

"We had an excellent first quarter and beat all analysts' expectations. I am confident our business is going very well for us. It continues to grow well and we are looking forward to substantial growth in the future," Horn said.
Horn said he believes his company has an 18-month technology lead over the competition and is going to fight hard to keep it that way.
In a sector where mergers and acquisitions are rife, Horn said Iona was on the lookout for suitable bedfellows as a matter of course.

"We have raised over $60 million in cash and we have no debt on the balance sheet," Horn said. "At this point in time, I am not aware of any acquisition offers to Iona nor are we in formal discussions on us acquiring anyone."

It is not Ireland's only success in the high-tech field. Investment incentives, a skilled English-speaking work force and a vigorous state investment body, IDA Ireland, have succeeded in making Ireland the software capital of Europe.

IDA Ireland says Ireland has become the market leader, attracting 30 percent of U.S. companies undertaking a new investment investment in Europe and is now the first choice of U.S. companies investing in Europe.

International conglomerates such as Intel Corp., Microsoft Corp., Hewlett-Packard Co., Novell Inc., Electronic Data Systems Corp. and International Business Machines Corp. have invested large amounts in facilities in Ireland.
